user_request: A Christmas poem about the magic of the season and family togetherness.

revision_history.draft:
Grandmother’s hands fold dough—  
a whisper of flour.  
The scent of pine resin  
mixes with cinnamon’s sigh—  
steam curls from the kettle’s mouth  
in a distant kitchen.  
Light fractures through the window’s dust,  
lace on the floor,  
a map of hours.  
Childhood breath fogges the glass,  
fingers tracing the fog’s slow dissolve—  
a ritual of warmth,  
unspoken,  
unbroken.

Grandmother’s hands fold dough—  
a whisper of flour,  
kneading time into shape.  
The scent of pine resin  
weaves with cinnamon’s sigh—  
steam curls from the kettle’s mouth,  
a distant kitchen’s breath.  
Light fractures through the window’s dust,  
lace on the floor,  
a map of hours unfolding.  
Childhood breath fogges the glass,  
fingers tracing the fog’s slow dissolve—  
a ritual of warmth,  
unspoken,  
unbroken.

final_poem:
Grandmother’s hands fold dough, a silent hymn—  
a whisper of flour,  
kneading time into a shape.  
The scent of pine resin weaves with cinnamon’s sigh—  
steam curls from the kettle’s mouth, a breath from the distant kitchen.  
Light fractures through the window’s dust, lace on the floor—a map of hours unfolding.  
Childhood breath fogges the glass, fingers tracing the fog’s slow dissolve—  
a ritual of warmth, unspoken, unbroken.
